div.head: 27.5.1885 Mittwoch
div.p: Arrived here this morning after a dreadful passage. When I awoke I noticed the ship was rolling very suspiciously; but I quickly got up threw on my clothes and went on deck where sat down. The motion of the machine was so dreadful though that I began to feel very funny. So I counted everything I could, trees, windmills, mountains to keep my attention occupied. At last I had to rush to the side and was dreadfully sick. I lay down then in the cabin and was alright till aunt Lulu called me to tell me we were in Göteborg. I was then again dreadfully ill and was glad to get on land where we drove to the Hotel Göta Källare (sp. Chaéllare). It was the first time I set my foot on Swedish ground. Very nice hotel. When we had washed we went down to breakfast. After breakfast wrote postcard, then jumped into a cab and drove as quickly as possible to the Station to go to the Trollhättan. Just as we came into the station the train whistled. I rushed onto the platform aunt Lulu after me. I caught hold of a door and had already opened it when a most impertinent man caught hold of it and shut it before our very noses and the train steamed out of the station. Aunt Lulu was dreadfully excited, began to cry, shrieked at me and every body else, so that It was quite fearful. At last I managed to quiet her and we went back to the Hotel. From there to Photograph Shop and by tram to the Slottkogen a very pretty park near here. We walked in it a little and then went back by tram and dined middlingly at the Hotel. After dinner took a drive in a very nice little victoria. The man first drove us to a kind of bellevue The way went through forests and rocks. The whole country here is covered with colossal boulders two or three hundred feet high, with here and there a patch of grass or a hardy tree hanging on to it. These boulders rise abruptly out of the valley as if some giant had strewn them about at random. Sometimes out of fruitful fields, sometimes out of a forest. Some of them are smaller, some regular mountains, but all equally desolate and jugged and contrasting strangely with the fruitful fields and the green forests which grow about their base. They are not single but rise in regular chains from the sea on one side up to the mountain on the other; From one of these boulders we had the view the coachman had driven us to see, and a fine one indeed. On one side the sea cutting right into the land, the steep rocks falling into it and the little red roofed houses strewn like nests around it, on the other the desert and desolate mountains with hardly a tree or a bit of grass on them and the fruitful valleys spreading around them. From here we drove through the town, which is really very fine, to another point de vue. Not so fine as the first. On the way saw lots of children. Remarkably pretty; large blue eyes, fair hair; almost all go barelegged and bare footed, and it is a pleasure to see them their legs and feet are so well made. In fact all Swedes are more or less handsome. I have never in my life seen such a handsome set of people. Slim, tall, beautiful skin. One can see they are the descendants of the Vikings of olden days. Almost all have got remarkably pleasant faces. From here we drove home through the Slottkogen. At Home I first wrote some postcards and then went out to change my photographs but did not do it as the others were too large. After this we went to a kind of musical garden, if one can call the place so, and there eat some ice-kagen. From there to Lorentzberg another such kind of garden. After having heard some music I went in search of a nightshirt as I have forgotten all mine in Copenhagen; but all th shops were shut. Afterwards dined and eat some Knackebrö which is delicious at dinner. In the morning we also went to the museum.
